timeline.bodyText:
what are the possible cases for exception and why are hiding them?
otherwise it looks like if there is some type of exception we're going to return an empty list to the client which is not correct.
so unless we're absolutely sure we want to swallow the exception, we shouldn't catch it and let an error be returned to the client

replies.bodyText: there is absolutely no situation where this code will throw an exception that needs to be handled because it is mostly local object sets and list/map functions. even if it is throwing an error it should be thrown back to the client YES!. i added it while simulating a test scenario in dev box and did not remove. i will take care of this
replies.author: jothi-prasad

timeline.bodyText:
Not sure why we're returning Map<String, Integer> here. if we add additional attributes, then this is not going to work thus is going to be changed again.
Looking at the server side, it looks like we're taking this Map<String, Integer> and then we generate List by filling the rest of the fields in the template meta objects. So why not just return here. the api should be:
List getDomainTemplates(String domainName);
then you just need fill in the other fields before returning to the client. in the future, if we need to add additional attributes, it would just require updating the TemplateMetaData object and not the api itself
timeline.author: havetisyan

timeline.bodyText:
there is no need to create this list again. we already have a list returned from dbservice. we should just add attributes and set that and return as part of our data. This way we're not just creating another set of objects which contains the same data as the original list. So just go through the list that we got on line 2629, update the objects and then on line 2650 we use that to set the meta data.
if we come across an entry that has not value then we should send it back since that shows something not right in the db - where we have a template that no longer exists in the server.
